title: Major Holidays
description: Explore Ethiopian Orthodox holidays, both fixed and movable, and understand the difference between official holidays and religious observances.

parts.title: Fixed Celebrations: Holidays That Never Change Dates

data.text: The Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church observes many holidays through fixed dates tied to the Ethiopian calendar. These holidays always fall on the same Ethiopian calendar dates, though their Gregorian dates shift slightly due to the calendar offset.

The Ethiopian Orthodox Church also celebrates monthly recurring holidays on fixed dates: Trinity on the 7th, Michael the Archangel on the 12th, Covenant of Mercy on the 16th, Holy Virgin Assumption on the 21st, Death of Our Lord on the 27th, and the birth of Christ on the 29th of each month.

points: Fixed to specific Ethiopian calendar dates
Always fall on same Gregorian dates (accounting for leap years)
Include both religious and national holidays

parts.title: Calculating Movable Feasts: The Bahire Hasab System

data.text: The calculation of movable holidays follows a set of ecclesiastical rules documented in a book called 'Bahire Hasab.' The primary movable holiday is Fasika (Easter), which determines the dates of other dependent feasts.

items: Cannot occur before Megabit 26 or after Miyazia 30
Easter Lent always begins on a Monday and cannot occur before Yekatit 1 or after Megabit 5

rows: Cannot occur before Megabit 19 or after Miyazia 23
Always begins on Thursday; cannot occur before Ginbot 5 or after Sene 9
Always begins on Sunday; cannot occur before Ginbot 15 or after Sene 19

data.text: The Easter calculation is based on the system of Ammonius, which uses lunar and solar calculations to determine the date. The Ethiopian Orthodox Church uses this ancient system rather than the Gregorian or Julian methods adopted by Western and other Eastern Christian traditions.

points: Easter determines other movable feast dates

data.text: Not all religious observances are official holidays. Understanding the difference helps clarify which days involve calendar closures and which are important religious commemorations.

items: All fixed Christian holidays (Enkutatash, Meskel, Gena, Timkat)
All national holidays (Victory of Adwa, Martyrs' Day, etc.)
Good Friday (ስቅለት) - only movable Christian holiday that's official
Ethiopian Easter (ፋሲካ) - only movable Christian holiday that's official
All Islamic holidays (Eid al-Fitr, Eid al-Adha, Moulid)

data.text: These observances are important to Orthodox Christians but are not recognized as official holidays by government or school calendars. They represent fasting periods, commemorative dates, and religious milestones that are observed within the church community.

points: Official holidays = calendar closures, recognized by government/schools
Religious observances = important to Orthodox Christians but not official holidays
Most movable Christian observances are not official holidays
